repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Sustainable Health System
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sustainable Health
            System Development Project for Madagascar were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: project management on the Bank side needs
            to be sufficiently thought through and adequately funded to
            ensure that there is sufficient support to implementation.
            An important contributing factor to the success of project
            implementation was the strong management of the project by
            the Bank and the implementing agency. With the Government
            firmly in the driver seat, the investment was seen as the
            next logical step in Bank support and was tailored with a
            comprehensive view of the sector in mind. The project was
            able to jump start implementation right after effectiveness
            because it took advantage of the capacity built in the areas
            of procurement and financial management. The implementation
            arrangements took advantage of Ministry of Health, Family
            Planning and Social Protection (MOH) staff in these areas
            that had been working on Bank projects. The project
            implemented pilots as a strategic way to test interventions
            with the intention of scaling up models that worked.
            Therefore, baseline data was collected and there was
            financing for proper evaluations. This should be considered
            good practice in the context of Bank operations.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Sustainable Health System
            Development Project (SHSDP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Madagascar Sustainable Health System
            Development Project (SHSDP) represents the next stage with
            respect to the World Bank and other development
            partners' support for the health sector. The project
            development objective of the SHSDP is to contribute to the
            strengthening of the health system and enhance the
            institutional capacity of the Ministry of Health to improve
            the access and utilization of health services, especially in
            rural and remote areas. The project includes the following
            components: 1) strengthening delivery of health services; 2)
            development and management of human resources in the health
            sector component; 3) innovations in health financing
            management; 4) improving demand and utilization of health
            services; and 5) institutional strengthening.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project development objective of the
            Health SWAP for Madagascar is to contribute to strengthening
            the health system, including financing, delivery and
            management, in order to improve the access and utilization
            of health services, especially in rural and remote areas,
            and scale-up the production and delivery of health programs
            with an emphasis on endemic infectious diseases,
            reproductive health (including family planning sexually
            transmitted diseases, and HIV/AIDS) andNutrition. The
            environmental management document aims at addressing
            appropriate mitigation and management measures to minimize
            impacts that may develop during the implementation of the
            project. Suggested mitigation measures are : used syringes
            must be discard immediately; syringes will not be used
            twice; toxic waste and bio-medical waste will disposed to a
            previously selected site; no bio-medical waste (BMW)
            management structure will be constructed within 100 meters
            of a surface waterbeds or wetlands; to preserve water supply
            sources; infectious waste, such as : sharps, chemical and
            pharmaceuticals, used radioactives, broken thermometers will
            be disposed to an incinerator or treated before sent to
            waste disposal site; encourage hospital staff to reduce
            medical waste by 50kg/daily; follow the norms of
            environmental and medical / hospital best practices prepared
            by the Ministry of Health, particularly during vaccination
            campaigns and everyday shots / injections given at hospital
            and clinics; never re-sterilize syringes; always follow-up
            for Manifestation of Adverse Post Injections (MAPI); comply
            with the joint declaration of OMS, UNICEF, FNUAP of December
            1999 when conducting vaccination campaigns; electrical and
            electronic equipment, tubes-lights and bulbs that becomes
            obsolete will be stored and sent for recycling; to reduce
            the effects of excessive noise, unloading bays, refuse
            disposal areas, boiler houses, workshops, laundry and
            kitchen areas should placed far from hospital sensitive
            areas; bio-medical waste will be placed in sealed drums and
            taken to appropriate places for disposal; waste water from
            toilets and bathrooms will be treated prior to discharged in
            to ground or natural drains; and finally, in general, adhere
            to Madagascar's legislation, codes of public health,
            and international conventions relative to health services
            (OMS, UNICEF and FNUAP of which Madagascar is a signatory,
            and the Bank's operational safeguard directives on
            health, nutrition and population.
